questions.text: "a" wave on JVP is for: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial contraction

 

 

The "a" wave on the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing represents atrial contraction. This wave occurs when the right atrium contracts, pushing blood into the right ventricle. It is the first positive deflection in the JVP waveform and is a key component in assessing right atrial pressure and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial filling: Incorrect. Atrial filling is represented by the v wave, which occurs as the atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole.

 

Option C. Ventricular relaxation: Incorrect. Ventricular relaxation corresponds to the x descent and y descent in the JVP tracing.

 

Option D. Ventricular filling: Incorrect. Ventricular filling is associated with the y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane represented below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Facilitated diffusion

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the process of facilitated diffusion. This type of transport involves the use of carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane to help molecules that cannot readily diffuse through the lipid bilayer move across the membrane, down their concentration gradient, without the expenditure of cellular energy (ATP).

 

  • Facilitated Diffusion: This process helps molecules move from an area of higher concentration to one of lower concentration via specific carrier proteins. It is a passive transport method since it does not require energy from ATP but relies on the concentration gradient.
  • Carrier Proteins: These proteins undergo a change in shape to transport molecules across the membrane. They are specific to the substances they transport, ensuring selective and regulated transport into and out of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple Diffusion: Involves the movement of molecules directly through the phospholipid bilayer without the assistance of membrane proteins, driven solely by their concentration gradient.

 

Option C. Primary Active Transport: Requires ATP to move substances against their concentration gradient via pumps.

 

Option D. Secondary Active Transport: Also known as co-transport, uses the gradient of one molecule to move another molecule against its gradient, indirectly using energy but not directly using ATP.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which mineral is important for sexual maturation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zinc

 

Explanation:

 

Zinc is the mineral most crucial for sexual maturation. It plays a significant role in several biological processes related to growth and development, particularly in the reproductive system. Zinc is essential for the stabilization of cell membranes and has anti-inflammatory properties. Moreover, zinc is crucial for the proper functioning and development of sperm, which directly links it to sexual maturation.

 

One of the key reasons zinc is important in sexual maturation is because of its role in the formation of zinc finger motifs. These motifs are a type of protein structure that binds to DNA and plays a vital role in gene expression, including genes involved in the development of sexual characteristics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Selenium is an essential trace element that plays a role in antioxidant defense and thyroid function. While it is important for general health, it is not as directly involved in sexual maturation as zinc.

 

Option B. Copper: Copper is important for various enzymatic reactions and the formation of red blood cells. Although it contributes to overall health, it is not specifically linked to sexual maturation.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium is critical for bone health and muscle function, but it does not have a direct role in sexual maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is the key mineral necessary for sexual maturation, particularly due to its role in the development and functioning of the reproductive system, including the formation of zinc finger motifs important for gene expression

choices.text: 125 ml/cm H20
150 ml/cm H20
50 ml/cm H20
62.5 ml/cm H20

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with respiratory volume of 500ml. The intrapleural pressure measured -4 before inspiration and -8 at the end of inspiration. The pulmonary compliance of the patient is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A) 125 ml/cm H20

 

The compliance of a system is defined as the change in volume that occurs per unit change in the pressure of the system.

 

Compliance is, therefore, a measurement of the elastic resistance of a system.

 

Pulmonary compliance (C) total compliance of both lungs, measuring the extent to which the lungs will expand (change in volume of lungs) for each unit increase in the trans-pulmonary pressure (when enough time is allowed for the system to reach equilibrium).

 

Compliance = Change in lung volume / Change in pressure

 

In the given case, change in lung volume is 500 and change in transpulmonary pressure is 4

Compliance = 500/4 = 125 ml/cm H20

 

Educational Objective

 

Pulmonary compliance measures the change in lung volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure. It is a crucial indicator of the lung's ability to expand and is affected in various pulmonary diseases.

choices.text: Subthalamic nuclei
Globus pallidus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient?   (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Explanation

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Putamen: Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Caudate nucleus: Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

questions.text: In a Pulmonary Function Test at what volume or capacity does the pressure measured at the upper airway reach zero?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

  • The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. It is measured by a spirometer.
  • FRC â†’ ERV + RV
  • At the lung volume corresponding to functional residual capacity (FRC), the lungs are in a relaxed state, and the pressure inside them becomes virtually negligible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation, but it does not correspond to the point where airway pressure is zero.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: Incorrect. Total lung capacity is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold, which includes all lung volumes, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Incorrect. Inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled after a normal expiration, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity is the lung volume at which the pressure in the upper airway reaches zero, indicating a relaxed state of the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a GPCR? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Muscarinic

 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors. Out of them, M1 and M3 act through Gq pathway and via the IP3/DAG pathway, whereas M2 and M4 act via Gi protein, that inhibits adenylyl cyclase leading to a decrease in the levels of cAMP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nicotinic: Nicotinic receptors are ionotropic receptors, which means they are ion channel receptors and not GPCRs. They allow the passage of ions across the cell membrane when activated.

 

Option C. GABA-A: GABA-A receptors are also ionotropic receptors that function as chloride ion channels. They are not GPCRs.

 

Option D. Insulin: The insulin receptor is a receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK), not a GPCR. It initiates a cascade of intracellular signaling upon binding insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that play a role in various physiological processes through different G-protein signaling pathways.

questions.text: Phase zero in the adjoining image is due to which of the following? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium influx

 

In the nodal tissue, Phase 0 is due to the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, which causes the rapid depolarization of the pacemaker potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium influx: While a slow influx of sodium occurs during the pacemaker potential's initial phase, it is not responsible for the rapid depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option C. Potassium influx: Potassium ions generally move out of the cell during repolarization and do not contribute to the depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option D. Potassium efflux: Potassium efflux occurs mainly during repolarization, which corresponds to phases 3 and 4 in the nodal tissue, not during the depolarization of Phase 0.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nodal tissue, such as the SA node, Phase 0 of the action potential is caused by the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to the rapid depolarization that initiates the action potential.

questions.text: As filtrate flows through PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

Normally in the PCT, Glucose & Amino Acid maximally approx. 100% reabsorbed; Bicarbonate approx.-80-85% and about 60-70 per cent of the filtered load of sodium and water and a slightly lower percentage of filtered chloride are reabsorbed by the proximal tubule before the filtrate reaches the loops of Henle. Hence, the concentration of chloride relatively increases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acid: The concentration of amino acids decreases significantly as they are almost entirely reabsorbed in the PCT.

 

Option B. Glucose: Glucose concentration also decreases drastically due to nearly complete reabsorption in the PCT.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: A large percentage of bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the PCT, leading to a decrease in its concentration in the filtrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), the concentration of chloride increases relative to other substances, which are more extensively reabsorbed. This includes glucose and amino acids, which are almost completely reabsorbed, and bicarbonate, which is substantially reabsorbed.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric endocrinology clinic by his parents due to concerns about his short stature compared to his peers. The parents mention that he has always been one of the shortest in his class and has not had the growth spurt typical of his age group. Physical examination shows that his height is below the 5th percentile for his age, and his growth velocity is significantly reduced. Laboratory tests reveal normal thyroid function but low levels of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I). The endocrinologist explains that IGF-I plays a critical role in stimulating growth, particularly during puberty. Which organ is primarily responsible for the synthesis of IGF-I?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Liver

 

Explanation:

 

The liver is the primary organ responsible for the synthesis of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I), which plays a crucial role in mediating the effects of growth hormone (GH) on body growth. IGF-I production in the liver is stimulated by GH secreted from the anterior pituitary gland. Once produced, IGF-I circulates in the blood bound to specific carrier proteins, extending its half-life and enhancing its bioavailability. IGF-I promotes cell growth, differentiation, and proliferation, particularly in bone and cartilage, making it essential for normal childhood growth and the growth spurt seen during puberty. The liver's role in IGF-I production is central to the body's growth regulation, with most circulating IGF-I originating from hepatic synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Muscle tissue
Muscle tissue is a target for IGF-I action, as IGF-I promotes muscle growth and repair, but it is not a major site of IGF-I synthesis. The liver remains the predominant source of circulating IGF-I in the body.

 

Option C. Kidneys
The kidneys play a role in erythropoietin production and regulate fluid and electrolyte balance, but they are not involved in the synthesis of IGF-I. The kidneys do not have a significant impact on growth regulation through IGF-I.

 

Option D. Bone marrow
Bone marrow is primarily involved in the production of blood cells and is not involved in the synthesis of IGF-I. Although IGF-I affects bone growth and remodeling, the primary production site of IGF-I is the liver, not the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) is predominantly synthesized by the liver in response to growth hormone stimulation from the anterior pituitary gland. IGF-I plays a critical role in growth by promoting bone and tissue development, with most of its circulating levels originating from hepatic synthesis. Understanding the liver's role in IGF-I production is essential for comprehending how growth hormone exerts its effects on body growth and development.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adipose tissue

 

Adipose tissue is dependent on insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Insulin stimulates glucose uptake into adipose tissue, promoting the storage of excess glucose as triglycerides in fat cells, thus regulating energy storage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain: The brain is capable of taking up glucose independent of insulin due to the presence of glucose transporter proteins that are insulin-independent, such as GLUT1. The brain has a high energy demand and relies heavily on glucose as its primary fuel source.

 

Option C. Pancreas: The pancreas does not take up significant amounts of glucose because its primary function is to produce and secrete insulin itself, among other hormones.

 

Option D. Kidney: The kidneys have glucose transporters, but they play a role in reabsorbing glucose from the urine back into the bloodstream rather than being dependent on insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adipose tissue is dependent on insulin for glucose uptake, which facilitates the storage of glucose as triglycerides in fat cells.

questions.text: The factors that can cause a person to drink water due to stimulation of thirst mechanism is/are? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Dehydration, hemorrhage, and prandial drinking: All three can cause increased thirst resulting in water drinking.

 

Option A. Dehydration: Loss of body fluids leads to increased osmolarity, which stimulates osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus, triggering the sensation of thirst.

 

Option B. Hemorrhage: Significant blood loss decreases blood volume and blood pressure, activating the thirst mechanism to restore fluid balance.

 

Option C. Prandial Drinking: Eating triggers signals that activate thirst neurons via SFO (Subfornical Organ) in the brain, prompting the urge to drink. This anticipatory drinking helps facilitate digestion and prevent future dehydration caused by ingested solutes.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm
Attachment of ATP to myosin head

questions.text: What leads to the detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Attachment of ATP to myosin head

 

Binding of ATP to the myosin head is what leads to the detachment of the myosin head from the actin filament during muscle contraction. The process of muscle contraction involves several steps where ATP plays a crucial role:

 

  1. Attachment of ATP: An ATP molecule binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from the actin filament.
  2. Hydrolysis of ATP: The myosin head, which has ATPase activity, hydrolyzes ATP into ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi). This hydrolysis provides the energy required for the myosin head to return to its high-energy, cocked position.
  3. Cross-bridge formation: The myosin head binds to a new position on the actin filament.
  4. Power stroke: The release of ADP and Pi from the myosin head triggers the power stroke, where the myosin head pivots and pulls the actin filament, causing muscle contraction.
  5. Repeat cycle: The cycle repeats as long as ATP is available and calcium ions are present to keep the binding sites on actin exposed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dissociation of ADP and Pi: This is involved in the power stroke, not in the detachment of myosin from actin.

 

Option B. Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm: This leads to muscle relaxation by causing the tropomyosin to cover the binding sites on actin, not directly to the detachment of myosin from actin.

 

Option C. Conformational change in Troponin T: This occurs when calcium binds to troponin, allowing tropomyosin to move away from the binding sites on actin, not directly related to detachment of myosin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detachment of myosin from actin filaments during muscle contraction is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which allows the myosin head to release from the actin and prepare for another cycle of contraction.

choices.text: Na- Ca transporter

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. SGLT1

 

Explanation

 

ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT2: Incorrect. SGLT2 is another sodium-glucose linked transporter but is primarily found in the kidneys where it reabsorbs glucose from the filtrate back into the bloodstream. It is not involved in intestinal glucose absorption and thus not relevant to ORS function.

 

Option C. GLUT4: Incorrect. GLUT4 is an insulin-regulated glucose transporter found mainly in adipose tissues and muscle cells. It is not involved in the intestinal absorption of glucose and plays no role in ORS therapy.

 

Option D. Na-Ca transporter: Incorrect. The sodium-calcium exchanger (often referred to as NCX) is primarily involved in the transport of calcium and sodium ions across the cell membrane in many tissues, including cardiac muscle. It does not participate in glucose absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LH

 

The Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) has a biological activity similar to that of Luteinizing Hormone (LH).

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a glycoprotein having a molecular weight of about 39,000 and much the same molecular structure and function as luteinizing hormone secreted by the pituitary gland. Its most important function is to prevent involution of the corpus luteum at the end of the monthly female sexual cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FSH: Incorrect. Although FSH is also a glycoprotein hormone, it has a different function and structure compared to hCG.

 

Option C. ACTH: Incorrect. ACTH is a peptide hormone involved in the stress response, with a different structure and function compared to hCG.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Incorrect. Oxytocin is a peptide hormone involved in labor and milk ejection, with a different structure and function compared to hCG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is structurally and functionally similar to Luteinizing Hormone (LH). Its primary role is to support the corpus luteum during early pregnancy, preventing its involution.

choices.text: Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla

questions.text: Pacemaker generating the rhythm for breathing is? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-Bötzinger complex

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex is a group of neurons located in the ventrolateral medulla of the brainstem, which is responsible for generating the basic rhythm of breathing. It is considered the primary respiratory rhythm generator, as it sets the pace for breathing and coordinates the activity of other respiratory neurons in the brainstem.

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex receives input from a variety of sources, including chemoreceptors, mechanoreceptors, and cortical areas, which help to adjust the respiratory rhythm based on changing physiological demands. It also sends signals to other respiratory centers in the brainstem, such as the dorsal respiratory group, which modulate the depth and rate of breathing.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pneumotaxic centre: Incorrect. It modifies the respiratory rate and pattern but does not generate the basic rhythm.

 

Option B. Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla: Incorrect. It regulates respiratory muscles and processes sensory information related to breathing but does not generate the primary rhythm.

 

Option D. Apneustic centre: Incorrect. It influences the pattern of breathing but does not generate the primary rhythm.

 

Educational objective

 

The Pre-Bötzinger complex, located in the ventrolateral medulla, is the primary respiratory rhythm generator. It sets the basic pace of breathing by generating rhythmic bursts of activity that drive the respiratory muscles, coordinating with other respiratory centers to modulate the breathing pattern based on the body's needs.

 

The pneumotaxic center and apneustic center are other respiratory centers located in the pons and medulla, respectively, which help to adjust the respiratory pattern by modifying the duration and intensity of inhalation and exhalation. The dorsal respiratory group is a cluster of neurons in the medulla that is involved in the regulation of respiratory muscles.

questions.text: The latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period of a skeletal muscle are 10 ms, 40 ms, and 50 ms respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 25 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as - 1/contraction period.

 

In this problem, contraction period is 40msec = 0.04sec

 

So, Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanization-  As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called Tetanization.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones do not act on the pancreas? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrin

 

Gastrin does not act upon the pancreas. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth.

 

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A. Secretin is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of acidic chyme. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice, which helps neutralize the acidity of the chyme entering the small intestine.

 

Option C. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of fats and proteins. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete digestive enzymes, including pancreatic amylase, lipase, and proteases, which aid in the digestion of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins.

 

Option D. GIP (Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide), also known as gastric inhibitory polypeptide, is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of nutrients, particularly glucose and fat. While its primary role is to stimulate the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells in response to elevated blood glucose levels, it also indirectly influences the pancreas by enhancing the release of pancreatic enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrin does not act on the pancreas. Instead, it stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth, while Secretin, CCK, and GIP have direct or indirect actions on the pancreas.

choices.text: Contraction of circular smooth muscle by acetylcholine
Release of norepinephrine from sympathetic nerves
Increased motilin secretion stimulating proximal contraction

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with symptoms of abdominal discomfort and altered bowel movements. During the evaluation, the gastroenterologist explains the mechanisms of peristalsis that facilitate the movement of food through the intestines. The patient is curious about how the intestinal muscles work during this process. The physician describes how the intestinal segment distal to the food bolus relaxes to allow smooth transit. What causes the relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Release of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP)

 

Explanation:

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus during peristalsis is primarily mediated by the release of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) from neurons in the enteric nervous system. VIP acts on smooth muscle cells by binding to VIP receptors, leading to the activation of intracellular signaling pathways that cause muscle relaxation. This process helps decrease resistance in the distal segment, allowing the bolus to move forward smoothly. VIP plays a critical role in coordinating the relaxation phase of peristalsis, ensuring efficient propulsion of contents through the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of circular smooth muscle by acetylcholine
Acetylcholine primarily stimulates contraction rather than relaxation. In peristalsis, acetylcholine causes the proximal segment to contract, pushing the bolus forward, but it does not contribute to the relaxation of the distal segment.

 

Option C. Release of norepinephrine from sympathetic nerves
Norepinephrine generally inhibits gastrointestinal motility by reducing muscle contractions and increasing sphincter tone, but it does not specifically cause the relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to a bolus during peristalsis.

 

Option D. Increased motilin secretion stimulating proximal contraction
Motilin enhances gastrointestinal motility by stimulating contractions, particularly in the migrating motor complex, but it is not involved in the relaxation of the distal segment during typical peristalsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to a bolus of food during peristalsis is mediated by the release of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) from the enteric nervous system, which acts on smooth muscle cells to induce relaxation. This mechanism is crucial for the coordinated movement of food through the gastrointestinal tract, facilitating effective digestion and absorption.

questions.text:
Calculate the ECF volume in a volunteer in whom 10 gm of mannitol was injected in venous blood. At equilibrium urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was 65 mg/100 ml?

In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 65 mg/100 ml. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 14L

 

ECF volume of the above volunteer is calculated to be 14 L.

 

Mannitol is a marker of ECF volume as it does not cross the cell membrane and remains in the ECF.

 

The ECF volume can be calculated using the formula:

 

 

Where,

 

  • V = ECF volume
  • Amount injected = 10 gm
  • Amount of mannitol excreted = 10% of 10 gm = 1gm

  • Plasma concentration of mannitol = 65 mg/100mL = 0.65 gm/L

     

Calculation:

 

ECF Volume = (10-1) /0.65 = 13.8 L = approximately 14 L

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extracellular fluid (ECF) volume can be calculated by using the dilution principle, taking into account the amount of marker substance injected, the amount excreted, and the plasma concentration of the marker.

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
 

Explanation

 

'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of right atrium: This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.

 

Option C. Passive filling of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

 

Option B. Globin part of hemoglobin: 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Globin part of myoglobin: 2,3-BPG does not bind to myoglobin. Myoglobin, primarily found in muscle tissue, has a higher affinity for oxygen and does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. Heme part of myoglobin: The heme part of myoglobin binds to oxygen directly; 2,3-BPG does not bind to this site or affect myoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option D. Heme part of hemoglobin: While the heme part of hemoglobin is the site for oxygen binding, 2,3-BPG does not bind here. It binds at a separate site on the globin chains to modulate oxygen affinity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  2. Repolarizing K+ currents
  3. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  4. Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

The ventricular action potential is characterized by a sequence of changes in membrane potential and ionic currents. The correct sequence is as follows:

 

  1. C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This is the initial depolarization phase (Phase 0). When the membrane potential reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, leading to a rapid influx of Na+ ions and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  2. D. Transient outward flow of potassium: This corresponds to Phase 1. Shortly after the peak of the action potential, transient outward K+ channels open, causing a brief efflux of K+ ions which results in a slight repolarization.
  3. A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is Phase 2, the plateau phase. Voltage-gated L-type calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ to enter the cell. The influx of Ca2+ is balanced by the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier K+ channels, maintaining a plateau in the membrane potential.
  4. B. Repolarizing K+ currents: This is Phase 3. The Ca2+ channels close, but the delayed rectifier K+ channels remain open, leading to a net efflux of K+ and returning the membrane potential to its resting value.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D. Transient outward flow of potassium

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

B. Repolarizing K+ currents

choices.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complains of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step of management in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irrigation of eye with normal saline

 

 

 

The initial management for any chemical injury to the eye, including chuna (lime) exposure, is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline. This step is crucial to wash out the chemical substance from the eye to minimize further damage. Immediate irrigation helps dilute and remove the chemical agent, reducing the risk of severe injury to the ocular tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics drops in eye: Antibiotic drops are important to prevent infection after the initial management, but they are not the first step. Irrigation must be done first to remove the chemical irritant.

 

Option B. Temporary tarsorrhaphy: Temporary tarsorrhaphy involves partially sewing the eyelids together to protect the eye, but this is not appropriate in the acute phase of a chemical injury. The eye needs to remain open to allow thorough irrigation and drainage of the chemical substance.

 

Option D. Complete Scraping: Complete scraping is a procedure to remove foreign particles embedded in the eye. While this might be necessary if there are chunks of chuna embedded in the conjunctiva, it is not the first step. The initial priority is to irrigate the eye to remove as much of the chemical as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of chemical injuries to the eye is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline to wash out the chemical substance

questions.text:
A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo abdominal fat pad biopsy instead of renal biopsy
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4

 

Following a renal biopsy, it is crucial to monitor the patient for potential complications, including bleeding and hematoma formation.

 

2. Observation post-biopsy: Patients should be observed for 24 hours following a renal biopsy to monitor for complications such as bleeding or infection.

 

3. Dark red clots in urine: Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy can indicate a hematoma. This is a potential complication that needs to be monitored.

 

4. Abdominal fat pad biopsy: Patients with systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo an abdominal fat pad biopsy as an alternative to a renal biopsy. This method can help diagnose systemic amyloidosis with less risk compared to a renal biopsy.

 

Other Option:

 

1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: This statement is incorrect. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can indeed be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy. The biopsy helps in identifying the characteristic histological changes associated with FSGS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-biopsy observation, recognition of biopsy-related complications, and alternative biopsy methods for systemic amyloidosis are essential in nephrotic syndrome management.

questions.text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal lady is detected by endometrial hyperplasia with atypia what is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

Postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia should be offered a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the very high risk of progression to malignancy. This approach effectively removes the source of hyperplasia and eliminates the potential for malignant transformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: High dose Progesterones can be used to manage endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, but this is not the recommended approach for atypical hyperplasia in postmenopausal women.

 

Option C. Mirena: The LNG-IUS (Mirena) can be recommended for those who want to preserve fertility and for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. However, it is not suitable for postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure may be used for diagnostic purposes but is not treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia in postmenopausal women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmenopausal women with atypical endometrial hyperplasia should undergo a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Ref: Page no 329, DC Duttaâ€™s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the organism given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Balantidium coli

 

The given image is the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli.

 

Balantidium coli occurs in two stages

 

  • Trophozoites are oval in shape and contain two nuclei. There is the presence of cilia over the entire surface and are larger around the mouth. Its anterior end is narrow and the posterior end is broad. At the anterior end, there is a groove leading to the mouth (cytostome). Posteriorly, there is a small anal pore (cytopyge).
  • Cysts are smaller, round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and many contractile vacuoles.

 

Living trophozoites/cysts are yellowish or greenish in color on wet mount.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba dispar: Entamoeba dispar is morphologically identical to Entamoeba histolytica but non-pathogenic. It does not have the characteristic cilia and shape seen in Balantidium coli.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium species are small protozoans that cause cryptosporidiosis. They appear as small, round oocysts and do not have cilia.

 

Option D. Giardia: Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan that causes giardiasis. Its trophozoites have a distinctive pear shape with flagella and two nuclei that resemble "eyes."

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balantidium coli is characterized by its oval shape, presence of cilia, and distinct anterior and posterior ends in the trophozoite form. The trophozoite stage contains two nuclei and is motile, while the cyst stage is smaller and round, aiding in transmission and infection.

questions.text: A patient, who consumed a large number of TCA pills during a depressive episode, presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG. What is the next best step in treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NAHCO3

 

A patient presenting with altered sensorium, hypotension, and wide QRS complexes on ECG following an overdose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) requires immediate treatment to address the cardiotoxic effects of the overdose. The best next step in this scenario is the administration of intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate (NAHCO3). Sodium Bicarbonate is used to treat the sodium channel blockade caused by TCAs, which is responsible for the wide QRS complexes. It works by alkalinizing the blood, which helps to mitigate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DC Cardioversion: This is generally used for unstable patients with life-threatening arrhythmias. In the case of TCA overdose, the priority is to treat the underlying cause of the arrhythmia (the sodium channel blockade), which is more effectively addressed with sodium bicarbonate.

 

Option B. Start antiarrhythmic drug: The use of antiarrhythmic drugs may be risky in the setting of TCA overdose, as these medications can exacerbate the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because there is a clear and specific treatment indicated for this scenario, which is the administration of Sodium Bicarbonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadockâ€™s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: Which structure serves as the control center for the stapedial reflex? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Superior olivary complex

 

Explanation:

 

The superior olivary complex (SOC) acts as the control center for the stapedial reflex, a critical auditory reflex that protects the inner ear from damage due to loud sounds. This reflex involves the contraction of the stapedius muscle in response to high-intensity sound waves, which stiffens the ossicular chain in the middle ear, thereby reducing the transmission of sound to the cochlea and preventing potential damage. The SOC integrates auditory input from both ears and coordinates the response, facilitating a bilateral stapedial muscle contraction even if the loud sound is perceived by only one ear.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B (Lateral lemniscus) is incorrect as this structure primarily acts as a pathway for ascending auditory signals rather than controlling reflex actions.
  • Option C (Inferior colliculus) is also incorrect; while it plays a role in auditory processing, it does not directly control the stapedial reflex.
  • Option D (Medial geniculate body) focuses on the relay of auditory information to the cerebral cortex and is not involved in reflexive auditory control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior olivary complex is pivotal in mediating the stapedial reflex, its role in auditory protection mechanisms.

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Standard deviation

 

  • Standard deviation is the Root of Mean od Squares of Deviations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance: Variance = (Standard deviation)2

 

Option C. Mean: Mean is obtained as sum of all values divided by the number of values in the distribution. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median: Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard deviation measures the dispersion of a data set around its mean.

questions.text: A child came to OPD with fever for 6 days with strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling of skin. What should be the ideal treatment? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IVIG

 

  • The constellation of symptoms described (fever, strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling skin) is suggestive of Kawasaki disease. IVIG is a key component of the treatment for Kawasaki disease to reduce the risk of coronary artery abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspirin: This is also a crucial part of the treatment for Kawasaki disease. Aspirin is used in Kawasaki disease to reduce inflammation and the risk of blood clot formation. However, it is often used in conjunction with IVIG.

 

Option C. Plenty of fluids: While maintaining hydration is important, fluid administration alone is not the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease. The use of IVIG and aspirin is more specific to address the underlying inflammatory process.

 

Option D. Cephalosporins: Cephalosporins are antibiotics and are not the appropriate treatment for Kawasaki disease, which is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Fever + 4 out of 5 below = Classic Kawasaki

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysticercosis cellulose

 

The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulose.

 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

 

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:

 

  • ï»¿ï»¿Epilepsy
  • ï»¿ï»¿Increased intracranial tension
  • ï»¿ï»¿Hydrocephalus
  • ï»¿ï»¿Psychiatric disturbances
  • ï»¿ï»¿Meningoencephalitis
  • ï»¿ï»¿Transient paresis
  • ï»¿ï»¿Behavioral disorders
  • ï»¿ï»¿Aphasia
  • ï»¿ï»¿Visual disturbances.

 

The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:

 

  • ï»¿ï»¿Scolex within a cyst
  • ï»¿ï»¿Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
  • ï»¿ï»¿Nodular calcifications
  • ï»¿ï»¿Focal enhancing lesions
  • ï»¿ï»¿Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

 

Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

 

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T. saginata: Incorrect. Known as the beef tapeworm, it does not typically lead to cysticercosis as its larvae (Cysticercus bovis) primarily infect cattle.

 

Option C. Cysticercosis bovis: Incorrect. This term is not applicable to human disease and refers to the larval stage of T. saginata found in cattle.

 

Option D. T. asiatica: Incorrect. This is a species of tapeworm similar to T. saginata and is associated with pigs, but like T. saginata, it is not commonly linked to neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis is identified with imaging studies, particularly in patients presenting with new-onset seizures and specific MRI findings of cystic lesions with scolex, is critical for timely diagnosis and appropriate management, including antiparasitic and supportive therapy.

choices.text: N - hydroxy cyclophosphamide
4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide
4 - acetyl cyclophosphamide
N - acetyl cyclophosphamide

questions.text: The active metabolite of cyclophosphamide is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide

 

  • Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating chemotherapeutic agent whose active metabolite is 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.
  • Side Effects:
    • Hemorrhagic Cystitis: One of the most notable side effects of cyclophosphamide is hemorrhagic cystitis. This is due to the accumulation of the metabolite acrolein in the bladder. To prevent this, mesna (a uroprotective agent) is administered alongside cyclophosphamide, and patients are advised to maintain adequate hydration.
    • Pulmonary Fibrosis: Another significant side effect is pulmonary fibrosis, which can affect lung function.
    • Bone Marrow Suppression: Like many chemotherapeutic agents, cyclophosphamide can also cause bone marrow suppression, leading to leukopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide's therapeutic effects are primarily due to its active metabolite, 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide. It is important to manage the side effects of cyclophosphamide, particularly hemorrhagic cystitis, through the use of mesna and adequate hydration. Pulmonary fibrosis and bone marrow suppression are other significant side effects to be monitored during treatment.

questions.text: A young donor came to the blood bank for the first time for platelet apheresis with platelet count of 1.9L. During the course he developed paraesthesia and circumoral numbness during donation. His vitals remained stable though. ECG showed tachycardia with ST-T changes. What is the reason for his symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypocalcemia

 

Hypocalcemia occurs due to citrate. It is due to calcium binding citrate anticoagulant used to keep blood from clotting in apheresis machine.

 

Treatment for this would be to slow down the flow of device and/or giving oral calcium supplements.

 

IV calcium is only required in case of prolonged apheresis as in case of HPC collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypovolemic Shock: This would be characterized by low blood pressure and signs of systemic shock, which are not described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Seizures: Although severe hypocalcemia can lead to seizures, the description focuses on paraesthesia and numbness, common early signs of hypocalcemia, without any mention of convulsive activity.

 

Option D. Allergic Reaction: The symptoms listed are not typical of allergic reactions, which might include hives, itching, or respiratory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During platelet apheresis, monitoring for symptoms of hypocalcemia is crucial due to the use of citrate. Symptoms such as tingling, numbness, and ECG changes warrant immediate evaluation and management, typically with calcium supplementation to counteract the effects of citrate.

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their corresponding criteria for the minimum number of lymph nodes required for pathological staging: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The minimum number of lymph nodes required for accurate staging are 16 for stomach carcinoma, 12 for colon carcinoma, 6 for gall bladder carcinoma, and 10 for breast carcinoma.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male recently underwent Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG). Within a few days after taking a saphenous vein graft, he complained of pain in the legs, and on examination, he had mild sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot on the side from where the graft was harvested. What is the nerve likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Saphenous nerve

 

The saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve that provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the leg and foot. During coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), the saphenous vein is often harvested for use as a graft. Due to its close anatomical relationship with the saphenous nerve, the nerve can be inadvertently injured during the vein harvesting process.

 

Injury to the saphenous nerve typically results in sensory disturbances such as pain, numbness, or tingling in the medial aspect of the leg and foot, which matches the patient's presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial peroneal nerve: The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot. Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss in these areas, not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve supplies the lateral aspect of the foot and the posterior lower leg. Injury to the sural nerve would not affect the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the posterior compartment of the leg and the sole of the foot. Injury to the tibial nerve would affect these areas rather than the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The saphenous nerve, due to its proximity to the saphenous vein, is at risk of injury during saphenous vein harvesting for CABG, leading to sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

choices.text: Intra-abdominal infections

questions.text: Antimicrobial combinations are used in all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gonorrhea

 

Drug of choice for treatment of gonorrhea is single dose ceftriaxone therapy. It does not require combination therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. For Management of Tuberculosis, a combination of drugs consisting of Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide and Ethambutol are used. In cases like MDR or XDR TB, other drugs like Bedaquiline, Levofloxacin, Ethionamide etc. are used in various combinations and in the form of different regimens.

 

Option C. Intraabdominal infections are generally polymicrobial in nature consisting of both aerobic and anaerobic microorganisms. Combination therapy with metronidazole and other agents like ciprofloxacin, cefepime, etc. are used as empirical agents to treat them.

 

Option D. Malaria: In case of Plasmodium vivax infection, Chloroquine is used for 3 days + Primaquine is added for 14 days. For P. Falciparum infection, combination therapy consisting of ACT-SP (Artesunate + Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine) are used along with a single dose of Primaquine on Day 2. For P. Falciparum infection in the north eastern states, ACT-AL (Artemether + Lumefantrine) is used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antimicrobial combination therapy is not used for the treatment of gonorrhea, which is typically managed with single-dose ceftriaxone therapy. In contrast, tuberculosis, intra-abdominal infections, and malaria require combination therapy to effectively manage the infections and prevent resistance.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with flaccid bullous lesions affecting both the oral cavity and the skin, as shown in the provided image, and exhibits acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear? (AIIMS May 2019
questions.solution:
Ans B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Flaccid lesions, mucosal involvement, and the presence of acantholytic cells are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated. Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3.

 

The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen. Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.

 

Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus foliaceus: Autoantibodies are seen against only Desmoglein 1, not against DsG 3, so there is no mucosal involvement in pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with multiple small Papulo-vesicles, which are extremely itchy and it is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

 

Option D. Bullous Pemphigoid presents as Tense bullae, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & it is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of flaccid bullous lesions affecting both the oral cavity and the skin, along with the observation of acantholytic cells on a Tzanck smear, is most consistent with a diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1-50.8

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 356

choices.text: 100% oxygen at 6 L/Minute
100% oxygen at 8 L/minute

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is: (INICET Nov 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subcutaneous sumatriptan

Acute Attack: Triptans, O2,

Preventive/prophylactic: Lithium CCB, Anti-convulsants

Subcutaneous triptans are preferred (best sumatriptan 6mg q24hrs) >> O2 @8L/min x 10 mins for treatment of acute attack

Prophylaxis is the cornerstone of therapy initiated at the time of acute attack and continued until patient is headache-free for at least 2 weeks

High dose steroids, Lithium, CCB(Verapamil) are effective options

Galcanezumab is used to reduce frequency of attacks!!

TAC (Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalgia)

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Headache/Chapter 430- Table 430-8

questions.text: What is the primary function of Hyperpolarizing Cyclic Nucleotide (HCN) gated channels? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Cardiac rhythm generation

 

Explanation:

 

Hyperpolarizing Cyclic Nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels are integral in generating the cardiac rhythm, particularly within the sinoatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes of the heart. These channels respond to hyperpolarization by opening, which allows for the influx of sodium and potassium ions. This ion movement leads to the generation of the 'funny current' ,crucial for initiating and regulating the pacemaker potential that dictates the timing of heartbeats. HCN channels thereby ensure the heart's rhythmic and consistent pumping action, supporting circulatory system functions.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B (Generation of mitochondrial action potential) is incorrect as mitochondria do not have action potentials in their typical physiological processes.
  • Option C (Myocardial muscle contraction) is also incorrect because HCN channels are involved in rhythm generation, not directly in the contraction of myocardial muscle.
  • Option D (Memory formation) is not the primary function of HCN channels in this context; while HCN channels are present in the brain and involved in neuronal activity and potentially memory, in the heart, their primary role is in rhythm generation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCN channels play a pivotal role in cardiac rhythm generation by initiating and regulating the pacemaker potential in the heart's conduction system.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

 

AMI refers to the sudden onset of intestinal hypoperfusion, which can be caused by an arterial embolism, arterial thrombosis, or venous thrombosis. Given the patient's history of ischemic heart disease (IHD), he is at risk for cardiac emboli. The symptoms described, such as severe diffuse abdominal pain out of proportion to the clinical findings with an absence of bowel sounds and vomiting, are typical for AMI. The irregular rhythm (possibly atrial fibrillation) increases the risk of embolization, leading to acute mesenteric ischemia, typically involving SMA leading to massive intestinal gangrene if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute severe pancreatitis: While this can cause severe abdominal pain, it typically presents with pain radiating to the back and is often associated with a history of alcohol intake or gallstone disease. The absence of bowel sounds might be seen, but other signs like fever, lack of increased amylase or lipase levels, and the nature of pain differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option B. Ruptured aortic aneurysm: This is a life-threatening condition that presents with sudden, severe pain. While it can cause hypotension, the nature of pain and other clinical findings (e.g., palpable pulsatile abdominal mass) can differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer perforation: A perforated peptic ulcer can lead to sudden, severe abdominal pain. However, this typically presents with a board-like rigid abdomen due to the spillage of gastric contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to acute peritonitis. This is different from the "soft" abdomen described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.

 

The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.

 

Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

 

Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid (Soft Chancre), a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy, not urethritis. Urethritis involves inflammation of the urethra, typically presenting with symptoms such as dysuria and discharge. H. ducreyi specifically causes ulcerative lesions rather than the typical inflammation and discharge associated with urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: While primarily known for causing trichomoniasis (a vaginitis), Trichomonas can occasionally cause urethritis, particularly in women.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly among sexually transmitted bacterial infections.

 

Option C. Gonococcus (Neisseria gonorrhoeae): A well-known cause of gonococcal urethritis, presenting typically with a more severe and purulent discharge compared to NGU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for using phenylbutyrate in urea cycle disorders? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It scavenges nitrogen

 

In urea cycle disorders ammonia cannot be converted to urea, but alternatively can be converted to glutamine and glycine. Ammonia scavengers phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate react with glutamine and glycine and consequently remove excess of ammonia. Phenylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in urine.

 

Phenylbutyrate is metabolized into phenylacetate, which conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. Similarly, sodium benzoate conjugates with glycine to form hippurate. Both phenylacetylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in the urine, thereby reducing the levels of ammonia in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It maintains renal output: While phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate are excreted in the urine, their primary function is not to maintain renal output but to remove excess ammonia.

 

Option C. It maintains energy production: Phenylbutyrate does not directly impact energy production. Its primary role is to help remove excess ammonia from the body.

 

Option D. It activates enzymes: Phenylbutyrate does not activate enzymes. Instead, it works by conjugating with amino acids to facilitate the removal of ammonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to scavenge nitrogen by reacting with glutamine, converting excess ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss. He has hypoglycemia and elevated alpha fetoprotein levels (250IU) but has normal AST and ALT. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis of the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

A history of chronic alcohol intake with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss is suggestive of a liver dysfunction.  

 

 

Other Options:

 

Differential Diagnosis:

 

Option A. Liver cirrhosis: Often has elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT) and may present with similar symptoms but is not typically associated with high AFP levels.

 

Option B. Hepatitis: Would show elevated AST and ALT levels, ruling out this option.

 

Option D. Cholangiocarcinoma: May present with jaundice and weight loss but is not typically associated with elevated AFP levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma should be considered in a chronic alcoholic presenting with abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss, hypoglycemia, and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, especially with normal AST and ALT levels.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain. During the medical examination, it is discovered that the patient has prostate cancer. The medical team suspects that the cancer may have spread to the lumbar vertebrae. What is the likely route of spread for prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostatic venous plexus

 

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae is primarily through the prostatic venous plexus or Bateson plexus. Tumor cells spread to the spine and proximal long bones via Bateson's venous plexus, which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.
  • The prostatic venous plexus (or Bateson plexus) is a network of veins surrounding the prostate.
  • The prostatic venous plexus has connections to the internal vertebral venous plexuses.
  • Because of this unique venous anatomy, tumor cells from the prostate can enter the venous system and bypass the usual portal and caval routes, spreading directly to the spine, specifically the lumbar vertebrae.
  • This is the most common route for metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans coelomic spread: Trans coelomic spread refers to the dissemination of malignant cells across body cavities, such as the pleural, peritoneal, or pericardial spaces. This method of spread is most commonly seen with primary cancers of the ovary, stomach, and colon. In the context of prostate cancer, trans coelomic spread is not a typical route to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Option C. Inferior vesical vein: The inferior vesical vein drains the urinary bladder. While there are venous communications between the prostatic plexus and the vesical veins, the direct spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae through the inferior vesical vein alone is less common than through the prostatic venous plexus.

 

Option D. Internal iliac vein: The internal iliac vein drains blood from the pelvis and perineum. While prostate cancer can spread through the internal iliac vein as part of its venous drainage, this route is not the primary pathway to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer primarily spreads to the lumbar vertebrae through the prostatic venous plexus (Bateson plexus), which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.

choices.text: Breast cancer on other side

questions.text: A 54-year-old female is diagnosed with unilateral breast cancer and is started on tamoxifen therapy by her oncologist. During a follow-up visit, the physician discusses the potential side effects of the medication with the patient. The physician specifically mentions that tamoxifen treatment can increase the risk of certain conditions specially cancer like: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial cancer

 

Tamoxifen, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), is commonly used in the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. While it provides therapeutic benefits in reducing the recurrence of breast cancer, it also has a known side effect of increasing the risk of endometrial cancer. This increased risk is due to tamoxifen's estrogen-like effects on the endometrium, leading to a higher incidence of endometrial hyperplasia, which can progress to cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian cancer: Ovarian cancer is not commonly associated with tamoxifen use.

 

Option C. Breast cancer on other side: Tamoxifen is actually used to decrease the risk of contralateral (other side) breast cancer in patients diagnosed with one side, thus it does not increase the risk.

 

Option D. Cervical cancer: Cervical cancer risk is not increased by tamoxifen; cervical cancer is primarily linked to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key educational takeaway is understanding the dual effects of tamoxifen in breast cancer therapy: its beneficial role in reducing the recurrence of breast cancer and its potential side effect of increasing the risk of endometrial cancer.

choices.text: Increased excitability of motor neuron pool

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a traumatic brain injury resulting from a motor vehicle accident. He is unresponsive with rigid extension of his arms and legs, hyperextension of the neck, and clenched jaws. His pupils are mid-position and non-reactive to light. Neurological examination reveals pronounced extensor posturing in response to painful stimuli. The medical team suspects decerebrate rigidity due to brainstem damage. According to Herrington classification, which of the following is not a characteristic of decerebrate rigidity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Presence of spinal shock-like phenomenon

 

Explanation:

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by rigid extension of all limbs due to brainstem damage, often occurring between the midbrain and pons. This condition results from the loss of inhibitory control from the higher brain centers, leading to uninhibited spinal reflexes. Key features include increased γ motor neuron discharge, heightened excitability of the motor neuron pool, and the involvement of antigravity extensor muscles. Unlike spinal cord injuries, decerebration does not cause a spinal shock-like phenomenon; instead, it directly enhances extensor muscle tone without a phase of flaccidity or loss of reflexes, distinguishing it from conditions that involve spinal shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased γ motor neuron discharge rate
This is a key feature of decerebrate rigidity, where the loss of descending inhibition leads to increased firing of γ motor neurons, which enhance the stretch reflexes and contribute to the sustained muscle contraction observed in decerebrate posturing.

 

Option B. Involvement of antigravity extensor muscles
Decerebrate rigidity prominently involves the extensor muscles, particularly those that counteract gravity. The overactivity of these muscles due to increased motor neuron excitability results in the characteristic rigid extension posture.

 

Option D. Increased excitability of motor neuron pool
Decerebrate rigidity involves increased excitability of the motor neuron pool due to loss of higher inhibitory input. This heightened excitability is responsible for the exaggerated reflexes and the sustained, involuntary muscle contractions seen in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by rigid extension of the limbs due to brainstem damage and loss of descending inhibitory control, leading to increased γ motor neuron activity and heightened motor neuron excitability. Unlike spinal injuries, decerebration does not produce a spinal shock-like phenomenon, differentiating it from other types of neurological rigidity or paralysis.

choices.text: Islam needle

questions.text: A bone marrow biopsy was indicated in a patient with unexplained anemia and following needle was used to extract specimen. Identify the instrument: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Klima needle

 

The given instrument is a Klima needle used for bone marrow biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salah's needle: Salah's needle is another type of biopsy needle but is different in design and is not commonly used for bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option C. Jamshidi needle: The Jamshidi needle is also used for bone marrow biopsies and is one of the most commonly used tools for this purpose. However, it has a different appearance compared to the Klima needle.

 

Option D. Islam needle: This needle is used for certain types of biopsies but is not typically associated with bone marrow biopsy procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Baroreceptor provides? (AIIMS Nov 2018
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative feedback

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies changes and does not stabilize blood pressure.

 

Option C. Both negative and positive feedback: Incorrect. Baroreceptors primarily provide negative feedback to regulate blood pressure.

 

Option D. Feedforward control: Incorrect. Feedforward control anticipates changes and adjusts accordingly, but baroreceptors respond to changes rather than anticipating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback to help maintain blood pressure within normal limits by triggering responses that counteract increases in blood pressure.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

 

The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy.

 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallium. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

 

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

 

  • Treponemes generally are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electron microscope: While capable of revealing detailed structures of microorganisms, it is not typically used in clinical settings for diagnosing infections due to its complexity and cost.

 

Option C. Light microscope: Standard light microscopy, typically used with staining techniques, does not easily allow for the visualization of live motility or very thin bacteria like Treponema pallidum.

 

Option D. Fluorescent microscope: Although it can be used to detect specific pathogens if fluorescent-tagged antibodies are available, it is not the standard method for observing motility or diagnosing syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is essential for observing the motility of Treponema pallidum directly from lesions such as a syphilitic chancre. This diagnostic tool is critical in early stages of syphilis when direct visualization of the pathogen can confirm infection before serological tests become positive.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

choices.text: Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax
Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy
Treatment of severe falciparum malaria
Treatment of endemic malaria in children < 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following is clinical use of tafenoquine? (AIIMS Nov 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radical cure of Plasmodium vivax
