Radical cure – Several patients of P. vivax malaria relapse due to persistence of exo-erythrocytic stage. Drugs which attack this stage (hypnozooites) given together with a clinical curative achieve total eradication of the parasite from the patient's body.

 

Drug of choice for radical cure of vivax and ovale malaria is:

 

  • Primaquine 15 mg daily for 14 days
  • Tafenoquine is a new long-acting exo-erythrocytic schizontocidal drug. It has been developed as a single dose radical cure for vivax malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy: Tafenoquine is not recommended for malaria prophylaxis in pregnancy due to its potential for causing hemolysis in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Pregnant women are typically advised to use other antimalarial drugs for prophylaxis.

 

Option C. Treatment of severe falciparum malaria: The treatment of severe falciparum malaria typically involves intravenous administration of drugs like artesunate or quinine, rather than tafenoquine. Tafenoquine is not used in this context.

 

Option D. Treatment of endemic malaria in children < 2 years: Tafenoquine is not recommended for use in children under 2 years of age. The safety and efficacy of tafenoquine in this age group have not been established, and alternative antimalarial therapies are preferred for young children.

 

Educational objective:

 

Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax malaria due to its long-acting effects against the exo-erythrocytic stage of the parasite, helping to prevent relapses.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 878

choices.text: Serum creatinine, urine creatinine concentration, urine volume, and collection time
Serum creatinine, age, gender, and body mass index
Blood pressure, serum sodium, urine potassium, and urine pH
Serum creatinine, body surface area, blood urea nitrogen, and serum albumin

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease is being evaluated for her renal function. To assess her glomerular filtration rate (GFR), her nephrologist asks her to collect her urine over 24 hours. What factors are necessary to calculate her creatinine clearance using the 24-hour urine collection method?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Serum creatinine, urine creatinine concentration, urine volume, and collection time

 

 

Explanation:

 

Creatinine clearance (Cs) is a measure of kidney function which is used to estimate the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). The calculation of creatinine clearance involves four critical factors: serum creatinine (Psâ€‹), urine creatinine concentration (Usâ€‹), urine volume (V), and the time over which urine is collected. The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance is:

 

This formula allows clinicians to assess how effectively the kidneys are clearing creatinine from the bloodstream. By measuring both urine and serum creatinine, along with the urine output over a specified time (typically 24 hours), healthcare providers can directly calculate the creatinine clearance and gauge renal function accurately.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Serum creatinine, age, gender, and body mass index
These factors are used in estimation formulas like Cockcroft-Gault and MDRD to approximate GFR, but they are not directly involved in the 24-hour creatinine clearance calculation.

 

Option C. Blood pressure, serum sodium, urine potassium, and urine pH
While important for overall renal and cardiovascular assessments, these factors do not contribute to calculating creatinine clearance directly. They are used more in evaluating electrolyte balance and renal tubular function.

 

Option D. Serum creatinine, body surface area, blood urea nitrogen, and serum albumin
Though these parameters can influence overall renal function assessments, they are not specifically needed for calculating creatinine clearance using the direct clearance formula.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To calculate creatinine clearance using the 24-hour urine collection method, serum creatinine, urine creatinine concentration, urine volume, and collection time are essential. This method provides a precise measure of renal function, helping to accurately assess glomerular filtration rate and guide clinical management in patients with kidney disease.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

 

Available HPV vaccines protect against either two, four, or nine types of HPV. All HPV vaccines protect against at least HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the greatest risk of cervical cancer. It is estimated that HPV vaccines may prevent 70% of cervical cancer, 80% of anal cancer, 60% of vaginal cancer, 40% of vulvar cancer, and show more than 90% efficacy in preventing HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers. They additionally prevent some genital warts, with the quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines that protect against HPV types HPV-6 and HPV-11 providing greater protection.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E6, E7: These proteins are oncogenes that contribute to the development of cancer by interfering with tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and Rb but are not components of the vaccine.

 

Option C. E1, E2: These are early proteins involved in the replication and regulation of HPV DNA but are not used in the vaccine formulation.

 

Option D. L2: This is a minor capsid protein of HPV, but the vaccine primarily uses the major capsid protein L1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

questions.text: A patient presented with biliary colic. The intern has administered an analgesic, following which the pain got aggravated. Which of the following could be responsible for the aggravation of the patient's symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Morphine

 

  • Morphine can cause the contraction of the sphincter of Oddi, which is a muscular valve that controls the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the small intestine.
  • In patients with biliary colic, the contraction of the sphincter of Oddi can exacerbate the pain and lead to complications such as pancreatitis.
  • Therefore, in patients with suspected biliary colic, it is important to use caution when administering morphine and to consider alternative analgesic medications such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or pethidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that does not cause sphincter of Oddi contraction and is unlikely to aggravate biliary colic.

 

Option C. Nefopam: Nefopam is a non-opioid analgesic that does not affect the sphincter of Oddi and is not likely to aggravate biliary colic.

 

Option D. Etoricoxib: Etoricoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor, another type of NSAID, which does not cause contraction of the sphincter of Oddi and is not likely to aggravate biliary colic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Morphine can exacerbate pain in biliary colic by causing contraction of the sphincter of Oddi. In patients with suspected biliary colic, alternative analgesic medications such as NSAIDs or pethidine should be considered to avoid worsening the condition.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD as he is always fatigued and has muscle cramps after exercise and the blood sample collected soon after exercise showed low glucose and lactate level. He became normal after resting for a while. Which of the following diseases is he most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McArdle disease

 

McArdle disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type V): This condition is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme myophosphorylase, which is essential for breaking down glycogen into glucose for energy during exercise. In McArdle disease, individuals experience muscle cramps, fatigue, and myoglobinuria (the presence of myoglobin in the urine) after exercise due to the inability to access stored glycogen for energy. Low glucose levels and lactate buildup can occur during exercise in individuals with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hers disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI): Hers disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme liver glycogen phosphorylase. It primarily affects the liver and leads to difficulties in releasing glucose from glycogen stores in the liver. This condition typically does not manifest with muscle symptoms like cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Option C. Cori's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III): Cori's disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme debranching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and muscles and can lead to muscle weakness, liver enlargement, and hypoglycemia. However, it does not typically present with the specific exercise-induced symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Andersen disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV): Andersen disease is a rare condition caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glycogen branching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and can result in liver fibrosis. It does not typically cause muscle cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The procedure in the image shows methylene blue dye being injected in the peritumoral region. What is this procedure used for? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

 

The utility of injection of methylene blue in the region around the tumor is for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB).

 

  • Methylene blue dye, along with other tracers, is commonly employed in sentinel lymph node biopsy procedures. Sentinel lymph nodes are the first lymph nodes that cancer is likely to spread to from a primary tumor. By injecting the dye around the tumor, these sentinel lymph nodes can be identified and biopsied to determine if cancer has spread to them. This helps in staging and planning further treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SLN biopsy rationale:

 

Afferent lymphatics from a primary tumor first drain into the sentinel node, before draining into the other nodes.

 

So, if sentinel lymph node is positive, it is possible that the other axillary nodes are also involved. Hence, axillary dissection would be necessary.

 

If the sentinel node is tumor free, then regional nodal metastasis is unlikely.

 

The nodes can be identified using:

 

  • Fluorescein dye
  • Methylene blue
  • Radioactive sulfur colloid-labeled albumin

 

The recommended site of injection is in the subdermal plexus surrounding the nipple.

 

This is used in patients with clinically node-negative disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her physician with concerns about missed periods and a positive pregnancy test. The physician explains that the pregnancy test detects the presence of a specific hormone in her urine, which is structurally similar to another hormone produced by the pituitary gland. Understanding this similarity helps explain the role of this hormone in maintaining early pregnancy. Beta hCG shares structural similarity with which biochemical molecule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Luteinizing Hormone (LH)

 

Explanation:

 

Beta hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin) is a glycoprotein hormone produced during pregnancy by the placental syncytiotrophoblast cells. Structurally, it closely resembles Luteinizing Hormone (LH), sharing a common alpha subunit and a similar beta subunit, though hCG has additional amino acid sequences that provide it with unique properties. The structural similarity between hCG and LH allows hCG to bind to LH receptors on the corpus luteum, preventing its involution and thereby maintaining progesterone production essential for sustaining early pregnancy. This functional overlap is crucial for supporting the pregnancy until the placenta assumes progesterone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin
Insulin is a peptide hormone that regulates glucose metabolism and does not share any structural components with beta hCG. It has a completely different function related to blood sugar control and energy regulation.

 

Option B. Growth Hormone
Growth Hormone is a peptide hormone that stimulates growth and cell reproduction. It does not share structural similarity with beta hCG and has no role in reproductive hormone regulation or pregnancy maintenance.

 

Option D. Cortisol
Cortisol is a steroid hormone produced by the adrenal cortex involved in stress response, metabolism, and immune regulation. It is structurally and functionally unrelated to beta hCG and does not interact with the reproductive system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG shares structural and functional similarities with Luteinizing Hormone (LH), enabling it to bind to LH receptors and prevent corpus luteum involution during early pregnancy. This interaction is crucial for maintaining progesterone production, which supports the early stages of gestation

questions.text: The following diagram depicts the fluctuation in population over the years spanning from 1983 to 1989 within a specific location. Which type of statistical diagram is being employed in this instance? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Component bar graph

 

  • The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.
  • A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.
  • In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Histogram is used for continuous quantitative data presentation.

 

 

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are

 

separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

 

In a histogram, the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

 

Option B. Line Diagram: Is a better chart Used in depiction of TREND. There is no closed loop and no histogram in the background.

 

 

Option D. Multiple Bar Graphs: Multiple bar graphs show two or more sets of data simultaneously with separate bars for each category side by side. This is different from a component bar graph, where each bar is divided into segments representing different components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A component bar graph is used to represent data where the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components, effectively illustrating the proportion of each category within the total value.

choices.text: 35 days and 42 days
21 days and 35 days
28 days and 45 days
35 days and 28 days

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct storage period when phosphate added to acid citrate dextrose (ACD) and when phosphate and adenine together added to ACD: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 21 days and 35 days

 

Explanation

 

The storage period when adding phosphate alone to ACD would be 21 days and when adding adenine and phosphate together would be 35 days.

 

ACD was developed into CPD (citrate-phosphate-dextrose) version with phosphate added intended to reduce phosphate leakage from red blood cells. It does not improve shelf life appreciably, but patient recovery is improved.

 

CPD with adenine (CPDA-1), which boosted RBC survival by improving ATP synthesis of RBCs to five weeks when combined with plastic bags.

 

CPD, in combination with adenine-mannitol additives such as SAGM, is the current blood bank preservative as of 2012.

 

RBC hemolysis, thus increasing the storage period to 42 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphate alone added to ACD allows for a blood storage period of 21 days, while the addition of both phosphate and adenine (as in CPDA-1) extends the storage period to 35 days, reflecting improvements in RBC viability through enhanced ATP synthesis.
